Indeed, LSTD can be seen as a greedy variant of ERP that trades global optimality of the matching with linear cost. Thus, LSTD utility is not confined to its efficiency, but it is also given by its direct relation to the problem definition. Finally, we notice that, given the different viewpoints adopted by EDR and LSTD, no direct relation between the values of the two measures is easily derivable.

On the efficiency side, LSTD has the same complexity of Euclidean distance (as it is also linear) between trajectories. However, the drawback of Euclidean distance is its inapplicability to trajectories having differing lengths, while this is not a problem for LSTD. Moreover, Euclidean distance is sensitive to outliers while LSTD is not, thanks to the truncation technique.
In the following we denote W4M L the variant of W4M which adopts LSTD distance instead of EDR.

div.head: Chunking
div.p: Our approach to deal with large databases consists in dividing the database into chunks, and treating each chunk as a separate database. After the chunking is complete, each chunk is then independently anonymized using W4M L , i.e., W4M with LSTD distance.

The simplest strategy for chunking is to randomly assigning trajectories to chunks. Clearly this approach, though very efficient, may produce very heterogenous chunks as similar trajectories will most likely be dispersed among chunks. As a result this strategy overly distorts the published data quality. Instead our strategy, named W4M L C , is based on partitioning the original database into large chunks using a simple trajectory distance computation. The objective is to put similar trajectories into the same chunk to reduce the data distortion. Obviously, this problem is as difficult as directly anonymizing the original database as pairwise distances between trajectories must be computed in order to put similar trajectories into the same chunk. We solve this problem by introducing an O(1) time pairwise trajectory distance computation, as explained next.

The distance function we adopt is essentially a comparison of the three-dimensional spatio-temporal bounding boxes of the two trajectories. Let t 1 and t 2 be two trajectories, then the distance we adopt is defined as the Euclidean distance between vectors /x min 1 ,x

div.head: Summary of the methods
div.p: To summarize, we have developed four methods:
NWA [2], pre-processing, followed by clustering based on Euclidean distance, and spatial translation;
W4M, clustering based on EDR distance followed by spatio-temporal editing;
W4M L , evolution of W4M which uses the more efficient LSTD distance in place of EDR distance.
W4M L C , further evolution of W4M L which uses also chunking to speed up the anonymization method.
These four methods are experimentally compared in the next section.

div.head: More experiments
div.p: In this section we report the final experimentation comparing the various members of the W4M family of methods and NWA. We coded our methods in C, and they are available in the corresponding webpages (links are in the first page of this article). All the experiments were performed on a Intel Xeon 2 GHz processor with 1 Gb of RAM over a Linux 2.6.14 platform. The settings of the experiments on the Oldenburg dataset that we report in the following are the same as described previously in Section 6.

div.head: Oldenburg dataset
div.p: Figs. 9 and 10 report run-time and range query distortion, respectively. It is immediately evident that the techniques, that we have introduced in Section 7 for efficiency purpose, achieve the intended goal of providing scalability without giving up quality of the data in the anonymized database. In particular, in Fig. 9(a) W4M L C exhibits one order of magnitude speed-up over the standard W4M on anonymizing the Oldenburg dataset.

It is worth noting that the Oldenburg dataset contains rather short trajectories. Given the quadratic behavior of EDR w.r.t. the length of trajectories, the gap in efficiency between the two methods is expected to grow with the length of trajectories. This is confirmed by the comparison in Fig. 9(b) where we anonymize only a subset of the Oldenburg dataset containing the 8000 longest trajectories: in this task, W4M L C is two orders of magnitude faster than EDR-based W4M.

This gain in efficiency is not paid in terms of quality of the anonymization. As shown in Fig. 10, the distortion introduced by W4M and W4M L C is always very close. For Possibly_Sometime_Inside range queries both methods have a distortion below 0.1 for all values of k and d, while NWA exhibits a distortion that grows up to 0.7 for large values of k. Instead for Definitely_Always_Inside range queries the distortion introduced by both W4M and W4M L C grows to between 0.4 and 0.5 for k=50 and larger.

Two observations are worth. First, W4M L C behaves extremely well, being in some cases surprisingly better than EDR-based W4M. The second observation is that W4M L , i.e., the version with LSTD but without chunking, performs always worse than both W4M and W4M L C . This clearly indicates a positive synergy of the two techniques: the chunking based pre-processing avoids LSTD to perform some poor trajectories grouping afterwards.

From the perspective of mining tasks, the results are slightly different, as shown in Fig. 11. In this case, we can see that performances, expressed in terms of F-measure, generally improve with W4M L , while chunking introduces some loss of quality, though rather limited.

Fig. 12 provides further insight in the behavior of the W4M family of methods. It reports statistics about the spatio-temporal editing phase, for those trajectories that are not trashed by the clustering phase (number of trajectories identified as outliers, and thus removed, are reported in Fig. 12(i), (j)). We can observe that W4M always performs the smallest number of points creations (Fig. 12(a), (e)) and points deletions (Fig. 12(b), (f)), while W4M L C performs less points creation but more points deletion than W4M L . Fig. 12(c) and (g) report the average temporal translation, and Fig. 12(d) and (h) the average spatial translation. Interestingly W4M L performs little spatial translations, while it performs rather large temporal translations. Also in this case W4M L C behaves more similarly to W4M than to W4M L , confirming the results obtained for range queries distortion.

div.head: Milan dataset
div.p: The large temporal extension of the Milan dataset (one week), the consequent length of trajectories, and the complexity of the city road network, made it unpractical to apply the basic EDR-based W4M algorithm, due to its high computational cost. Therefore, in the following we report experimental results using only W4M L C . The parameters used are Max_Trash ¼ 10% of the dataset, and initial max_radius ¼ 2000 (2 km).

This real-world dataset is not only more challenging computationally, but it is also an harder anonymization task: trajectories are much more complex and heterogeneous both in space and time, making very difficult to preserve the data quality in the anonymization process. Fig. 13 summarizes the results. In the first row of plots we report the effects of the spatio-temporal editing. The number of created and removed points (Fig. 13 grows with larger k and smaller d as expected, and it is rather high being approximately around 1 9 of the total number of points in the input database for k= 50. However points created and removed by the spatio-temporal editing are in the same order, thus balancing the total effect. Fig. 13(c) shows average spatial translation being between 4 and 6 km for k=50 and being larger for smaller d. Fig. 13(d) shows average temporal translation being almost always between 1 and 2 h for k= 50, while being much smaller for small k, and much larger for k= 100 when d is small. The number of trajectories trashed by the algorithm (Fig. 13(e)) decreases for larger k, apparently suggesting that larger values of k make it easier to form groups of limited diameter. This is due to chunks size in the chunking pre-processing being a multiple of k: with larger k, the larger variety of trajectories in each chunk can abundantly balance the stronger density constraints imposed over clusters.

Run time, shown in Fig. 13(f), grows linearly w.r.t. k, and is almost independent from d. This confirms the theoretical evaluation of the complexity of W4M L C : the Finally, the effects of anonymization on the extraction of frequent sequential patterns is shown in Fig. 15(a)-(c). In this case, a minimum support threshold of 0.35% was adopted, yielding 8204 frequent patterns on the original dataset. The results in Fig. 15(a) are coherent with those obtained over the Oldenburg dataset, showing an Fmeasure that is very high for small values of K, keeping above 50% for K =30 and most values of d (all excepted 200, the smallest one). Fig. 15(b) shows the precision obtained on the same experiments, i.e., the ratio of patterns obtained on the anonymized dataset that were already present in the original data, while Fig. 15(c) shows recall or coverage, i.e., the ratio of patterns present in the original data that were preserved by anonymization. In both cases we have very high performances for small values of K, especially in the case of coverage, which are kept around or above a sound 40% for values of K up to 50, confirming the good quality preservation achieved by the W4M approach.

div.head: Conclusions, extensions and open issues
div.p: We studied the problem of anonymity preserving data publishing in moving objects databases and introduced the concept of (k,d)-anonymity, that exploits the inherent uncertainty of location in order to reduce the amount of distortion needed to anonymize data. We deeply characterized the problem and developed various methods to solve it. In particular we first recalled our previous proposal NWA which is essentially a greedy clustering method for trajectories equipped with ad hoc preprocessing and techniques to produce compact clusters at the price of suppressing some outliers. Starting from a discussion on the limits of NWA, we then developed a novel method ðW4MÞ that, being based on EDR distance, has the important feature of being time-tolerant. W4M embeds various interesting techniques. To the best of our knowledge our algorithm is the first to use EDR as distance function within a trajectory clustering framework, thus providing further assessment of the merits of this distance. Another novel idea that we introduced is to exploit the EDR computation also as a guide on how to perform the last step of the anonymization process, i.e., the spatio-temporal editing. Faced with the quadratic complexity of W4M, we developed techniques aiming at making it scalable, without giving up quality of the result. In particular, we reduced (i) the quadratic time of the distance computation to linear time, and (ii) the quadratic time on the number of trajectories to sub-quadratic time. The first was achieved through the introduction of a novel spatio-temporal distance function, named LSTD, while the second was achieved by means of chunking (i.e., pre-clustering) of original set of trajectories. The introduction of LSTD measure for trajectories has its own merits. Being linear, LSTD has the same computational cost of Euclidean distance, but it has not the same limits: in fact LSTD is time-tolerant, can be applied to trajectories of different length, and it is tolerant to outliers. Indeed, it represents a good practical trade-off between Euclidean and EDR.

We performed an extensive experimentation on both synthetic and real-world datasets. Data quality was assessed both by means of objective measures of information distortion and by more usability oriented measure, i.e., by comparing the results of spatio-temporal range queries and frequent pattern mining, executed on the original database and on the anonymized one. Experimental results confirmed what was expected: (i) that W4M provides better quality anonymization than its predecessor NWA, but it is computationally more expensive; (ii) that W4M evolution with LSTD and chunking is much more scalable than EDR-based W4M while achieving similar levels of quality in the anonymization. One interesting result of our experiments is that anonymizing the real-world dataset is a much more challenging task than the synthetic one. This result highlights the need of having more real-world MODs available for researchers working in the area.

Although experimental results show that our method introduces reasonable distortion, there is still room for improvements. In particular, we aim at devising more sophisticated techniques to automatically handle the trade-off between cluster radius and trash size.

In this article we assumed a uniform uncertainty level d for all the moving points. In some applications this could not be the case, and different moving objects could have different uncertainty level d. Our method can be straightforwardly extended to deal with this situation by taking, for each cluster, the minimum d appearing in the cluster.
However, more sophisticated techniques should be devised.

One limitation of our work is that we do not keep directly in consideration, as possible background knowledge, the road network [54][55][56]. In particular, in the space translation step in NWA an hypothetical mean trajectory is computed for each cluster, and all trajectories within the cluster are space translated towards the mean. The motivation with the mean trajectory is to minimize the translation distortion (Lemma 1). Although the mean trajectory technique makes sense with free terrain movement model, in the road network model the mean trajectory might violate the road constraint. One possible solution to enforce the road network constraint is to use the median trajectory instead of the mean trajectory in the space translation step. We define the median trajectory (of a cluster) as the closest trajectory to the mean. For W4M we do not need any change as it is already geared on the pivot, which is an existing trajectory in the MOD.

Obviously the inherent uncertainty d of the system, might make some trajectories violate the road network, as it happens sometimes with GPS navigator systems. We believe that directly including the road network constraint in MOD anonymization problem formulations will open up interesting research directions; as in privacy aware mobile services [55] and knowledge hiding in MOD [56].

It has been recently recognized (e.g., in [11] and in many other papers) that k-anonymity alone does not put us on the safe side, because although one individual is hidden in a group (thanks to equal values of the quasiidentifiers), if the group has not enough diversity of the sensitive attributes then an attacker can still associate one individual to sensitive information. Also in the MOD context, if we are able to know that one individual belongs to a group, even if we are not able to identify exactly his trajectory, we can still discover some sensitive information. However, in the context of moving object data the problem is very challenging, because position is a peculiar kind of information that could be considered to be sensitive and quasi-identifier at the same time. Therefore, since anonymity requires similarity on the quasiidentifiers, and diversity requires dissimilarity on the sensitive information, it seems that in the case of moving object data they are two conflicting goals. In this paper we did not consider any concept of quasi-identifier for trajectories, and thus we did not tackle the diversity problem: these are interesting and open research problems that deserve deep investigation.

Finally, finding a realistic and actionable definition of quasi-identifiers in the MOD context, as well as devising methodologies to derive them, are important open problems. most 4m for ðk ¼ 3,d ¼ 0ÞÀanonymity on D. To prove the claim we first give the following lemma: Lemma 2. For any subset of rows with cardinality t, the minimum translation cost for a column with q number of 1's and (t À q) number of 0's is 2 Á q Á ðtÀqÞ=t.
Proof. Since the mean of the subset for the column is q/t and d ¼ 0, translation distortion cost for the subset on the column is the q Á ð1Àq=tÞþðtÀqÞ Á q=t ¼ 2 Á ðq Á ðtÀqÞ=t.

The distortion cost evaluates to zero (which is the minimum cost possible) when the column is homogenous (contains all 0's or 1's). Moreover, for the heterogenous case (mixture of at least one 1 and at least one 0), the minimum is obtained when there is either exactly one 1 or exactly one 0. In that case, the distortion cost evaluates to 2 Á ðtÀ1Þ=t. & Direction: Edge Partition ) ðk,dÞÀanonymity: In case G is a collection of triangles and 4-stars, (k ¼ 3,d ¼ 0)anonymity can be obtained with at most the distortion of m Á 3 Á 2 Á ðtÀ1Þ=t ¼ m Á 3 Á 2 Á 2 3 ¼ 4m. This is because every triangle and 4-star have exactly the same cost of 3 Á 2 Á ð2Þ

3 and there are exactly m such structures. Recall that from Lemma 2 each column of a triangle or 4-star contributes to distortion cost either 0 (homogenous columns) or 2 Á 2 3 (heterogenous columns, two 1's and one 0 or vice versa) and there are three heterogeneous columns.

Direction: Edge Partition ( ðk,dÞÀanonymity: Suppose there is a (k ¼ 3,d ¼ 0)-anonymity solution with at most 4m distortion cost. Since any three rows differ at least in three columns, the solution should have at least m Á 3 Á 2 Á 2 3 ¼ 4m distortion cost. In case there are solutions which group more than three rows, i.e., t 4 3, they must have at least t heterogenous columns and the minimum possible cost of such grouping is t Á 2 Á ðtÀ1Þ=t. The average distortion per row is then ð1=tÞ Á t Á 2 Á ðtÀ1Þ=t ¼ 2 Á ðtÀ1Þ=t which is minimized when t =4 with the average cost of 3 2 ¼ 1:5. This is the lowest distortion per row of any such setting. Recalling that the minimum distortion per row when t =3 is 4 3 ¼ 1:33, hence the total distortion of 4m is possible only when t = 3 and there are m such groupings.
This concludes that there is an exactly TTD=4m solution for (k ¼ 3,d ¼ 0)-anonymity iff the G is a collection of triangles and 4-stars.

Since we want a reduction from the edge partition into triangles, we need 4-stars to give more distortion than triangles do. In the sequel we show the equivalence of (k ¼ 3,d ¼ 0)-anonymity to edge partition into triangles.

Equivalence to Edge Partition into Triangles: The reduction is as follows. We replicate the columns of D (constructed above) all together where each replication is called a block and initialize all entries with 0's. The number of blocks is l ¼ 2 Á dlg 2 ð3m þ 1Þe and therefore the number of columns is 2 Á jVj Á l. Labels are assigned as explained before and replicated as well. For any arbitrary ordering of edges (from 1 to 3m) we assign the respective binary number to the edge. For instance, if m= 100, then the edge with the ordinal 5 is assigned with the binary code of 000000101. Then we append binary codes with complements. In the above example, for instance, the code becomes 000000101111111010. Note that, the length of all the codes are equal to the number of blocks l. For each row, each block is either in configuration 0 or 1 and it is decided based on the binary code of the edge. For instance, in the above example the edge with ordinal 5 is in configuration 0 in blocks 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 16 and 18 while in 1 in blocks 7, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15 and 17. For each row corresponding to the edge e ¼ ðv,uÞ 2 E and for each block, we put 1 to the entry v x and 2 to the entry u x in configuration 0, but 2 to the entry v x and 1 to the entry u x in configuration 1.

We claim that G is a collection of only triangles iff the minimum translation distortion (TTD) cost is at most 6ml for ðk ¼ 3,d ¼ 0Þ-anonymity. Direction: Edge Partition ) ðk,dÞ-anonymity: In any block, there are eight possible configurations for any triplets of rows, from binary 000 to 111 where the first digit is the configuration of first edge, and so on. All possible triplet configurations for a triangle are illustrated in Table 2 with distortion costs. As it is clear from the table, each block has distortion cost of exactly 6. Since we have m triplets and l blocks we have a ðk ¼ 3,d ¼ 0ÞÀanonymity solution with cost at most 6ml where each triangle contributes exactly 6l.
Direction: Edge Partition ( ðk,dÞ-anonymity: Here, we show that any 4-star contributes distortion cost larger than 6l. We construct a table similar to Table 2 for a 4star.

Recall that our reduction always pairs a configuration with its complement. From Table 3, the minimum distortion of 4-star is obtained when the configuration is 000 or 111, the average value is (8+ 4)/2= 6. In this case, the cost is exactly the same as to the triangles. In other words, the theoretical limit for a 4-star is at least 6l. However, this limit cannot be reached because of the reduction as edges are assigned different binary codes and they should switch to some heterogenous configuration (other than 000 and 111) more than once, otherwise they should have the same binary code which is by construction impossible. For any switching case, note that sum of any complementing pairs in Table 3 (which is 8+ 6.67= 14.67) is greater than the respective sum in Table 2 (which is 6+ 6= 12). Therefore, the distortion should be larger than 6l for any 4-star.

Given a dataset of trajectories D T all defined over the same time interval T, an uncertainty threshold d and an anonymity threshold k, transform D T into D 0 T such that: D 0 T is the same set of trajectories D T , possibly containing space translated points, D 0 T is ðk,dÞÀanonymous, and total translation distortion TTDðD T ,D 0 T Þ is minimized. Theorem 2. The ðk,dÞ-anonymity by space translation problem is NP-hard.Proof. See Appendix.

The algorithm iteratively selects a chunk of trajectories and anonymizes them by means of W4M L . Given the anonymity threshold k, the size of chunks is 20k except the last one which has at most 2 Á 20k trajectories. The chunk selection, based on the O(1) simple trajectory distance measure defined above, is executed at line 7 of Algorithm 8.

note.p: It is worth noting that in the original paper introducing EDR[3], the matching with tolerance is defined only w.r.t. the x and the y, with no mention at all of the temporal dimension. This corresponds to have D:t ¼ þ1. We prefer to introduce the possibility of controlling also the tolerance admitted on the time dimension: this makes the definition more general and more suitable for real-world applications. O. div.head: Appendix A
div.p: In the following we provide the proof of Theorem 1: (k,d)-anonymity by point suppression problem is NP-hard.

Proof. NP-hardness of k-anonymity by attribute suppression for transactional data has been proven in [12], by reduction from the Edge Partition Into Triangles problem. Our proof is a simple reduction from the k-anonymity with attribute suppression that is defined as follows: given transaction database D r and anonymity threshold k obtain k-anonymous variant of D r by introducing minimum number of suppressions. We obtain the instance of (k,d)-anonymity with point suppression problem by setting D T ¼ sðD r Þ,d ¼ 0 and T ¼ ½t 1 , . . . ,t m where m is the number of attributes in D r , and s : R-R Â R is element-wise dimension augmentation operator such that sðxÞ ¼ ðx,0Þ. The intuition is to treat each column in D r as the x dimension of a spatial point and adding a fake y dimension whose value is always 0. Under this reduction these two problems become the same. &
In the following we provide the proof of Lemma 1: with space translation of points, the minimum distortion is obtained by moving all points to the mean of the cluster.

Proof. From Definition 4 we observe that translation distortion TD decomposes (as summations) across the clusters ðP ¼ fp 1 , . . . ,p n gÞ and also across timestamps ðt 2 TÞ. Therefore, it suffices to address independently the cost contribution of any cluster at any timestamp to TD. Additionally, constraining d ¼ 0 implies that locations of trajectories within any cluster should be moved to the same point at any t 2 T. Thus in this setting we have a set of two dimensional points to be clustered. The analytical minimization of the well-known least-square of errors gives that cluster center is the mean point. &
In the following we provide the proof of Theorem 2: ðk,dÞ-anonymity by Space Translation problem is NP-Hard.

Proof. Our proof is based on a reduction from the Edge Partition into Triangles problem which is defined as follows. Given a graph G=(V,E) such that jEj ¼ 3m, the problem asks whether there is a way of partitioning edges into m triangles. For convenience, we first show the equivalence to edge partition into triangles and 4-stars and then we show the equivalence to edge partition into triangles. & Equivalence to Edge Partition into Triangles and 4-stars:

The reduction is very similar to Aggarwal et al. [12] as given next. From the graph G, D with 3m rows are created (one row for each edge). For each of the vertices v 2 V, we create two consecutive columns referred v x and v y . The table is initialized with all 0's. For each row, we put 1's to the entries v x and u x if the corresponding edge is e ¼ ðv,uÞ 2 E. So, this way each row contains two 1's and the table contains 6m 1's. Anonymity threshold is set to k= 3 and uncertainty threshold is set to d ¼ 0.
